record.textContent:
One of the best things about PowerShell is that you can interactively explore anything.  Long before the Wiggum Loop was a thing, PowerShell let you explore interactively with prompting.  Here's how you can embody the spirit of Ralph Wiggum and find your way around PowerShell.
All parts of the PowerShell Wiggum Loop are as old as PowerShell itself.
To be fair, the Simpsons did it first (1989).
PowerShell did it second (2006).
Generative AI came a lot later (~2020)
We used to call this many things that didn't imply you were an idiot.  I'm calling this the "PowerShell Wiggum Loop" now only to make it easier to understand.
We used to call it:
The Trinity of Discoverability
The basic "exploration / implementation" loop looks like this: Find a command, try to figure out how to use it, run it, see what it produces.This loop was included three common commands, dubbed the Trinity of Discoverability
They are:
Get-Command
PowerShell commands tend to be named with verb-noun pairs.  Most people try to be as obvious as possible.
With that in mind, getting commands is pretty obviously named.  To Get commands in PowerShell, you just run:
Get-Command
When this runs you'll see (almost) every command currently loaded.This will vary depending on your OS, what modules you have installed, and what you have loaded.
Get-Command has plenty of parameters.  One of the most useful is probably -Syntax.To see the syntax of Get-Command, we run:
Get-Command Get-Command -Syntax

To see all of the commands from all Modules starting with Microsoft.*, we'd use:
Get-Command -Module Microsoft.*
We can also get all commands of a -Verb.  Let's get all the gets:
Get-Command -Verb Get
We can also look for nouns.  Let's get all the -Module commands:
Get-Command -Noun Module
And of course, we just search by wildcard:
Get-Command Get*
If we want to scope it down to a given type of command, we can use -CommandTypeSo, if we wanted to see if ffmpeg was installed and in the path, we could:
Get-Command ffmpeg* -CommandType Application
Get-Help

To get help, we can, just:
Get-Help
